title: Everglades National Park: North Nest Key Sound Gallery
body: Explore This Park    Learn About the Park     Nature     Environmental Factors     Soundscape / Noise     North Nest Key Sound Gallery                  North Nest Key Sound Gallery         North Nest Key facilities. NPS photo  Below, listen to a Gulf toadfish recorded at North Nest Key, a small key located in the northeastern part of Florida Bay. Keep in mind that a backcountry permit is required to camp at all backcountry campsites in the park, including North Nest Key.        Gulf toadfish. Photo courtesy Texas Parks and Wildlife Department  Toadfish are one of only a few fish species that make sounds loud enough for people to hear. Try a round of Name That Tune: Everglades Edition to see if you can distinguish the sounds of a Gulf toadfish from those of an Eastern screech owl.             Gulf Toadfish     Listen to a Gulf toadfish recorded at the North Nest Key site.     Credit / Author: NPS Natural Sounds Program   Date created: 2008-04-20                Spectrogram of Gulf toadfish. Also called sonogram, spectral waterfall, voiceprint, or voicegram, a spectrogram is a visual representation of the spectrum of frequencies in a sound that can be used to analyze the various calls of animals. The horizontal axis represents time and the vertical axis represents frequency. The amplitude of a particular frequency at a particular time is represented by the intensity of color at each point in the image. Image courtesy NPS Natural Sounds Program        Acoustic monitoring sites in Everglades National Park.
